Stoke City made it five wins in their last seven matches with a 2-0 victory over Burnley at the bet365 Stadium.
Walters looped a deft finish over Paul Robinson after a piece of skill and cross from Mame Biram Diouf on the right.
Marc Muniesa’s first career Premier League goal on his 50th appearance made it 2-0 before half-time.
Burnley, who have just a point away from home, could not find a way past Lee Grant, who denied Andre Gray late on.

Jermain Defoe scored his eighth Premier League goal of the season to help Sunderland beat Leicester City at the Stadium of Light.
Robert Huth's own goal broke the deadlock before Defoe doubled Sunderland’s lead with an opportunistic finish on 77 minutes.
Substitute Shinji Okazaki grabbed a goal back for Claudio Ranieri’s team with 10 minutes left, and they put pressure on Sunderland’s goal.
But goalkeeper Jordan Pickford made a stunning save from Wes Morgan in stoppage time to secure the points that lift Sunderland off the bottom of the table.

Tottenham Hotspur returned to winning ways with a comprehensive 5-0 victory over Swansea City.
After losing their unbeaten Premier League start at Chelsea in Matchweek 13, Harry Kane, Son Heung-min and Christian Eriksen all scored at White Hart Lane.

West Bromwich Albion made it three wins from four Premier League matches with goals from Jonny Evans, Chris Brunt and Matt Phillips.
Christian Kabasele’s goal gave Watford hope with 30 minutes left, the Belgian bundling the ball in from a corner after a save by Ben Foster.
Roberto Pereyra was dismissed for fouling James McClean, before Phillips sealed the win in the final minute.
Tony Pulis’s side climb one place to sixth, overtaking Manchester United, while Watford stay in 10th.

Alexis Sanchez scored a 14-minute hat-trick as Arsenal eased past West Ham United 5-1 at London Stadium.
The Gunners took the lead on 24 minutes, when Sanchez raced through to square to Mesut Ozil to tap into the empty net.
West Ham answered back when Andy Carroll, shortly after coming on, nodded in after Dimitri Payet’s free-kick had hit the woodwork.
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain scored from distance to make it 4-1 before Sanchez completed his treble and moved joint-top of the scoring charts with 11 goals, racing through, dummying and chipping in.
Alexis Sanchez

Stoke City moved into the top half of the Premier League table thanks to a narrow victory over Watford at Vicarage Road.
Their winning goal came in the 29th minute when Charlie Adam's header came off the post and rebounded off goalkeeper Heurelho Gomes into the net.
Giannelli Imbula, making a return to the Potters' starting line-up, went close with a long-range shot as the visitors controlled the opening period.
Watford responded in the second period, with Daryl Janmaat and Stefano Okaka having opportunities, but they could not claim the equaliser and had Miguel Britos sent off late on for a second yellow card.

Arsenal battled to a 3-1 home victory against AFC Bournemouth thanks to an Alexis Sanchez double.
But AFC Bournemouth refused to roll over, and Callum Wilson levelled from the spot on 23 minutes after Nacho Monreal was adjudged to have fouled the Cherries striker.
Eight minutes after the break, Theo Walcott headed Arsenal back into the lead from Monreal left-wing cross.
Petr Cech had to make an excellent point-blank save with 14 minutes left from former Arsenal manBenik Afobe and visiting substitute Lys Mousset missed a golden chance to level in the final minute.
As AFC Bournemouth continued to push for an equaliser, Olivier Giroud set up Sanchez for the late goal that puts fourth-placed Arsenal four points clear of Tottenham Hotspur in fifth, and drops Eddie Howe's side to 11th.
Man of the match: Alexis Sanchez

Manchester United were held to their fourth successive home draw for the first time since 1980 as they came from behind to share a point with West Ham United in an enthralling match at Old Trafford.
United fell behind to the second earliest goal they have conceded in a Premier League match, when Diafra Sakho headed Dimitri Payet's free-kick past David De Gea with just 90 seconds gone.
Jose Mourinho's side levelled on 21 minutes through Zlatan Ibrahimovic, who rose to head Paul Pogba's searching pass past Darren Randolph.
In an eventful first half, in which Man Utd manager Jose Mourinho was sent to the stands, Randolph's boot denied Marcus Rashford when he was put clean through on goal andthe visiting goalkeeper also turned Jesse Lingard's header wide of goal.
In a breathless second period Randolph saved from both Lingard and Pogba, but the Hammers, who might have scored themselves had De Gea not saved from Ashley Fletcher late on, held on for the point that lifts them to 16th place.

A first-minute goal from Charlie Austin proved the difference between the teams on Everton manager Ronald Koeman's return St Mary's Stadium.
Southampton manager Claude Puel handed a debut to 19-year-old debutant Josh Sims and he was immediately at the heart of the action, first having a shot blocked, then crossing for Austin to nod in after just 41 seconds.
Everton struggled for fluency before the break, while Sims caused them plenty of problems on the right wing.
Yannick Bolasie had a couple of shots after the break as Everton searched for the equaliser, while Romelu Lukaku went close with a free-kick.
Maarten Steklenburg pulled off a brilliant save from an Austin header with half an hour to go, then did superbly to deny James Ward-Prowse, and Puel was thrilled to see Southampton hold firm for their first win in five in the Premier League.

Manchester City returned to the top of the Premier League, ahead of other matches, thanks to Sergio Aguero’s double in a 2-1 victory at Burnley.
Aguero shook off injury concerns to start but Burnley took the lead on 14 minutes.
Ashley Barnes had an overhead kick saved by Claudio Bravo for Burnley as Man City hung on to move two points clear of Chelsea before their late match against Tottenham Hotspur.

Michael Dawson earned Hull City a 1-1 draw to deny West Bromwich Albion a third successive Premier League victory.
Matt Phillips’ corner was headed in by Gareth McAuley for a half-time lead for Tony Pulis’s men.
Robert Snodgrass had a free-kick saved by Ben Foster before the Scot supplied the telling cross that Dawson converted.

An Islam Slimani penalty in stoppage time earned a 2-2 draw for Leicester City against Middlesbrough at the King Power Stadium.
Alvaro Negredo put Boro ahead on 13 minutes, sweeping in Gaston Ramirez's cross, before Shinji Okazaki struck the bar for Leicester.
Calum Chambers's handball allowed Riyad Mahrez to equalise from the spot, but, with 20 minutes left, Negredo restored Boro's lead, finishing Adam Forshaw's ball over the top.

Liverpool returned to the top, albeit briefly, of the Premier League with a hard-fought 2-0 win over Sunderland at Anfield.
Jurgen Klopp's team dominated for long periods but were hit by the first-half withdrawal with injury of Philippe Coutinho.
With 15 minutes remaining the deadlock was broken through Coutinho's replacement, Divock Origi, whose curling effort beat Jordan Pickford at his far post.
The win was sealed in stoppage-time when Didier Ndong fouled Sadio Mane and James Milner converted from the spot.

Fernando Llorente struck twice in stoppage time as Swansea City fought back to beat Crystal Palace 5-4 at the Liberty Stadium.
Palace took the lead through Wilfried Zaha but Gylfi Sigurdsson levelled from a free-kick before half time.
Swansea took control of the second half as Leroy Fer scored twice in two minutes.
Palace fought back and three goals in nine minutes, from James Tomkins, a Jack Cork own goal and Christian Benteke, put them 4-3 up as the clock reached 90 minutes.

Chelsea returned to the top of the Premier League with a fightback that marked seven consecutive wins and ended Tottenham Hotspur’s unbeaten start.
Chelsea did little to threaten the Spurs goal until Pedro turned and curled in an equaliser on the stroke of half-time.
Diego Costa ran down the left and crossed to the far post, where Victor Moses converted.
Marcos Alonso missed a great chance to make it 3-1

West Bromwich Albion returned to the top half of the Premier League table after claiming a comfortable victory over Burnley at The Hawthorns.
The Baggies, who defeated defending PL champions Leicester City last time out, went ahead on four minutes when Matt Phillips fired into the roof of the net when a James Morrison cross was diverted into his path by Dean Marney.
Jeff Hendrick lofted the ball wide as Burnley rallied but the Baggies doubled their lead through Morrison, who finished off a fine counterattack on 16 minutes.
Salomon Rondon's curling shot was well saved by Burnley's Tom Heaton before Darren Fletcher made it three eight minutes before half-time, finishing after Phillips chipped the ball to the back post.

Chelsea earned their sixth successive Premier League victory without conceding thanks to Diego Costa's strike in a 1-0 win at Middlesbrough.
Middlesbrough played their part in an action-packed encounter at a sold-out Riverside Stadium, but Costa's 10th goal of the season put Chelsea top of the league.
After Boro goalkeeper Victor Valdes superbly tipped over Pedro's rising strike, Costa reacted quickest to prod the ball into the net when his header from an Eden Hazard corner was blocked.
The fast pace continued after the break, with Pedro rattling the crossbar before Victor Moses blasted over following a rapid Chelsea counter-attack.
Thibaut Courtois saved well after Alvaro Negredo's brilliant control and strike late on for Boro, who are in 15th place on 11 points.

Olivier Giroud struck in the 89th minute to earn Arsenal a 1-1 draw against Manchester United at Old Trafford.
United looked destined for a home win after Juan Mata had given them the lead with a 68th-minute strike, the Spaniard converting Ander Herrera's cross.
But with the clock ticking down two substitutes made the difference for Arsenal, as Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain's right-wing cross was Marcos Rojo might have made it 2-0 but headed wide and it came to haunt United as Arsenal’s

Yaya Toure capped a surprise return to the Manchester City starting XI with two goals to earn a 2-1 win over Crystal Palace at Selhurst Park.
But City responded and Toure was allowed to convert Kevin De Bruyne’s low corner to send City level on 27 points with Liverpool.

An 89th-minute header from Seamus Coleman denied Bob Bradley a first win as Swansea City manager.
Gylfi Sigurdsson’s penalty in the 41st minute put Swansea on course for victory after Phil Jagielka, on his 300th Premier League start, had fouled the Icelander.
Yannick Bolasie had a chance for an immediate equaliser, but shot straight at Lukasz Fabianski when clean through.
Further opportunities were missed by Romelu Lukaku and Ross Barkley but after Bolasie's cross was not cleared by Swansea, Coleman's looped header rescued a point.

Southampton stemmed Liverpool’s goal flow to earn a share of the points at St Mary’s Stadium.
Forster dived to his left to deny former team-mate Sadio Mane after 28 minutes.
Philippe Coutinho had a chance to open the scoring after Roberto Firmino sent him through, but struck wide.
Firmino twice went close late on as Liverpool dominated, although Charlie Austin headed wide Southampton’s best chance of the match late on.

Nathan Ake marked his first Premier League start for AFC Bournemouth with the winner at Stoke City.
’s team took the upper hand early on and after Lee Grant had denied Joshua King, took the lead on 26 minutes, when Ake headed in Junior Stanislas’s free-kick.
Steve Cook cleared a Ryan Shawcross effort off the line after 40 minutes but Stoke's best chance came from the penalty spot.

Sunderland recorded a second successive Premier League win, beating Hull City 3-0 at the Stadium of Light, thanks to a Victor Anichebe double.
Hull started the brighter but could not get past Jordan Pickford, who denied Sam Clucas.
Sunderland broke the deadlock on 34 minutes with Jermain Defoe’s 150th Premier League goal, a typical smart finish.
After a floodlight failure that forced the players off for five minutes early in the second half, when play resumed Sunderland doubled their lead when Anichebe scored with his left foot.

Watford scored two early goals and held off a Leicester City fightback to secure a 2-1 win at Vicarage Road. 
The Hornets made a great start when Etienne Capoue volleyed in on 33 seconds after a neat flick-on by Troy Deeney.
The home side doubled their lead on 12 minutes courtesy of Roberto Pereyra’s curling effort.
Claudio Ranieri's side reduced the deficit almost immediately through Riyad Mahrez's penalty after Jamie Vardy had been fouled by Miguel Britos.
Leicester pressed for an equaliser after the break but could not find the goal that would have secured a second point on the road this season.

Harry Kane struck twice in two minutes at the end to earn Tottenham Hotspur a 3-2 win over West Ham United.
Michail Antonio had put West Ham ahead in the 24th minute, heading in Winston Reid’s cross-cum-shot.
Spurs levelled six minutes after the break when Harry Winks scored on his first Premier League start by following up Vincent Janssen’s saved shot.
West Ham went back in front on 68 minutes after Janssen pulled down Reid to concede a penalty that Manuel Lanzini converted.
West Ham, who had Reid sent off in stoppage time for two bookings, remain 17th, a point off the bottom three.
Harry Kane

Harry Kane scored from the spot on his return to the Tottenham Hotspur starting line-up to give his side a draw in the north London derby, extending their unbeaten start to the Premier League season.
Arsenal, who would have gone top of the table with victory at Emirates Stadium, recovered after Kane headed Christian Eriksen's cross just wide to have the better of the opening half.
Alex Iwobi fired at Hugo Lloris when played in by Alexis Sanchez while Theo Walcott's powerful shot hit the woodwork before Kevin Wimmer headed into his own net from a Mesut Ozil free-kick just before half-time.

Hull City scored two goals in two second-half minutes to claim a comeback victory over Southampton, their first win in nine Premier League matches.
The Tigers looked to be heading for a seventh straight league defeat when Charlie Austin stroked home a sixth-minute penalty after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida in the area.
But Hull refused to lie down and Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a first-half substitute, equalised on 61 minutes when he coolly finished from Sam Clucas's cut back.Snodgrass then turned provider when his free-kick was headed home by captain Michael Dawson.
Hull goalkeeper David Marshall saved from Austin and Clucas headed off the line late on as Southampton chased an equaliser but the home side held on to secure their first league win since 20 August.

Sadio Mane scored twice as Liverpool beat Mane added to goals from Philippe Coutinho,Emre Can, Roberto Firmino and Georginio Wijnaldum as Liverpool claimed their seventh win in eight Premier League matches, moving a point above Chelsea at the top of the table.
Liverpool took the lead through Mane’s header and Coutinho added a quickfire second with a fine 20-yard strike. Adam Lallana’scross found Can to head home a third just before half time andLiverpool’s superiority continued after the break.
Daryl Janmaat pulled a goal back for Watford

Manchester United returned to winning ways with a 3-1 Premier League success against Swansea City.
Zlatan Ibrahimovic made it 2-0 with the 25,000th goal in Premier League history, a low strike from the edge of the box, before the Swedish striker slammed in the third after Wayne Rooney’s second assist of the day, his 100th in the PL.

West Bromwich Albion ended Leicester City’s 20-match unbeaten home record in the Premier League with a 2-1 victory on Sunday.
Leicester’s impressive home streak was a catalyst to their 2015/16 PL title triumph, but James Morrison put the visitors in front on his first top-flight start since January.

David Moyes, watching from the stands, saw his Sunderland side fall behind to a Dan Gosling goal after 10 minutes.
On 31 minutes, Victor Anichebe levelled with his first goal since signing this summer, rifling past Artur Boruc from inside the box.
AFC Bournemouth took control after the break, especially when Steven Pienaar received a second yellow card, but Jordan Pickford stood out in the Sunderland goal.
The visiting side went ahead through Jermain Defoe's penalty, won by Anichebe, in the 74th minute and held on to move level with Swansea City on five points.

Ashley Barnes netted a 94th-minute winner as Burnley beat Crystal Palace 3-2 at Turf Moor.
Sam Vokes opened the scoring in the second minute before Johann Berg Gudmundsson’s first PL goal made it 2-0 shortly after.
Connor Wickham smashed home Wilfried Zaha’s right-wing cross on the hour and with nine minutes to play Christian Benteke levelled from the penalty spot.

Marten de Roon scored a last-gasp header for Middlesbrough to snatch a 1-1 draw against Manchester City.
Sergio Aguero had poked homeKevin De Bruyne's right-wing centre shortly before half-time after the hosts had dominated.
City goalkeeper Claudio Bravo made two early second-half saves, from Alvaro Negredo's shot from the halfway line and from Adam Forshaw as Boro fought back.

Bojan scored his second goal of the season to earn Stoke City a 1-1 draw with West Ham United.
The substitute converted a cross from Jonathan Walters 15 minutes from time.
West Ham had led 10 minutes earlier through an own goal by Glenn Whelan, who deflected in Michail AntonioAngelo Ogbonna had forced Lee Grant to save his powerful first-half header from a corner, while Dimitri Payet’s free-kick skimmed just over the bar on the stroke of half-time.
Charlie Adam nearly won it for Stoke when his late free-kick was saved by Adrian.

Chelsea returned to the top of the Premier League with an emphatic victory over Everton.
Seventy seconds later it was 2-0 as Marcos Alonso arrived unmarked to convert Pedro’s cross.
Diego Costa made it three before half-time from a corner.
Hazard produced the goal of the match on 56 minutes, exchanging flicks with Pedro before beating Stekelenburg again.
Pedro completed the scoring for an exhilerating triumph that takes Chelsea a point clear of their rivals ahead of Sunday’s matches.
Eden Hazard

Wilfried Bony scored twice against his old club as Stoke City beat Swansea City 3-1 at the bet365 stadium.
The striker, who joined on loan from Manchester City two years after leaving Swansea, netted his first Premier League goal for Stoke on three minutes, turning in Joe Allen’s miscued shot.
Wayne Routledge levelled five minutes later when he headed in Gylfi Sigurdsson’s cross.
Trickery and a shot from substitute Ramadan Sobhi, on for the injured Xherdan Shaqiri in the first half, forced an own goal from Swansea

Romelua Lukaku scored for a seventh consecutive Premier League match against West Ham United to help Everton return to winning ways with a 2-0 victory at Goodison Park.
Pedro Obiang fired over for West Ham early on before goalkeeper Adrian saved superbly from Everton's Ross Barkley in a goalless first half.
Lukaku struck on 50 minutes, heading in Yannick Bolasie's cross for his 50th Premier League goal for Everton.
Michail Antonio, Andre Ayew and Mark Noble had chances to level for West Ham but Everton ensured victory when Barkley scored with a half-volley from Lukaku's cross on 76 minutes.
The result ended a run of four league matches without victory for Everton while West Ham are in 16th with their first defeat in four fixtures.

Diego Costa reclaimed the sole lead in the Premier League scoring charts, while Chelsea returned to the top four with a fourth win a row, triumphing 2-0 at Southampton.
Chelsea were ahead at St Mary’s after just six minutes, Hazard finishing through Fraser Forster’s legs.
Forster, meanwhile, had to save from Hazard and Diego Costa.
Southampton thought they had a goal back on 85 minutes through Charlie Austin but the striker was just offside.
Chelsea are a point behind the top three, while Southampton are ninth.

Substitute Olivier Giroud scored with his first two touches of the match as three goals in seven minutes helped Arsenal beat Sunderland 4-1.
After Alexis Sanchez headed in Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain’s cross in the 19th minute, Sunderland hit back in the second half when Petr Cech brought down Duncan Watmore and Jermain Defoe scored from the spot.
He hooked in Keiran Gibbs’ cross before heading in his second from Mesut Ozil’s corner.
Sanchez cleverly poked the ball past Jordan Pickford to seal the win against Sunderland who remain bottom and without a win.

Burnley had goalkeeper Tom Heaton to thank as they secured their first away point of the season with a hard-fought 0-0 draw against 10-man Manchester United.
Substitute Wayne Rooney could have won it for United in stoppage time but his shot from the edge of the box flew just over.

Middlesbrough secured their first home win of the season as goals from Gaston Ramirez and Stewart Downing saw off AFC Bournemouth.  
Ramirez opened the scoring six minutes before half-time, finishing low with his right foot after a run from the halfway line.  
Downing doubled Boro's advantage on 56 minutes with his first Premier League goal for the club since May 2008, finishing off a headed knockdown by Alvaro Negredo. 
AFC Bournemouth pushed hard for a goal but rarely threatened Victor Valdes’s goal.
Middlesbrough climb to 13th, two points behind their opponents, who remain 10th.

Tottenham Hotspur remain unbeaten in the Premier League this season but had to share a 1-1 draw with champions Leicester City at White Hart Lane.
That pressure told just before half-time when Vincent Janssen was brought down by Robert Huth in the box and the Dutchman converted the spot-kick for his first Premier League goal.
Jamie Vardy surged down the right and his cut back was rifled in my Ahmed Musa for the Foxes' equaliser.
Jan Vertonghen clattered the crossbar with a late header but Leicester gained their first away point of the campaign in north London.

An late own goal from Michael Dawson consigned Hull City to a 1-0 defeat at Watford, their sixth in a row.
Watford dominated the opening proceedings as Younes Kaboul headed against the bar from a corner in the fourth minute.
Hull nearly took the lead after the break but Abel Hernandez shot straight at Heurelho Gomes when through on goal.
The breakthrough came in the 82nd minute when Nordin Amrabat’s cross picked out Roberto Pereyra and his shot cannoned off Dawson and into the net for Watford to clinch the points and continue their best start to a PL season.
Sergio Aguero and Ilkay Gundogan each scored twice as Manchester City beat West Bromwich Albion 4-0 to return to the top of the table.

Liverpool moved level on points with Manchester City and Arsenal at the top of the table with a 4-2 win at Crystal Palace.
Lovren atoned for his error three minutes later by heading in Philippe Coutinho’s corner but was outjumped by McArthur, who headed Palace level again on 33 minutes.
An unmarked Joel Matip made it 3-2 for Liverpool just before the break, from another Coutinho corner.
Christian Benteke had three chances for another equaliser after the break and Roberto Firmino made the match safe on 71 minutes when he dinked Jordan Henderson’s through-ball over Steve Mandanda.

Manchester City came from behind to earn a 1-1 draw with Southampton and return to the top of the Premier League on goal difference.
Southampton took the lead when Redmond pounced on a back pass from John Stones intended for Vincent Kompany - the City captain making his first PL appearance since 19 April - and rounded Claudio Bravo to silence the Etihad Stadium.
Iheanacho replaced De Bruyne at half-time and within 10 minutes had equalised, meeting Leroy Sane's low, left-wing centre.
City threatened a second with Ilkay Gundogan and Iheanacho thwarted by Fraser Forster but City, who move on to 20 points along with Arsenal and Liverpool, had to settle for a point.

Chelsea moved up to fourth place in the Premier League table after producing a superb display to sweep aside Manchester United 4-0 and to spoil former manager Jose Mourinho's return to Stamford Bridge.
The home side had the perfect start when Pedro latched onto a long pass, took the ball around the advancing David De Gea and stroked it home with only 30 seconds on the clock - the fastest Premier League goal of the season.
Zlatan Ibrahimovic headed just over from an Antonio Valencia cross soon afterwards but Chelsea doubled their advantage on 21 minutes, defender Gary Cahill firing in when a loose ball from a corner fell into his path.
United started to exert some pressure at the start of the second period, Jesse Lingard's shot forcing a good save from Thibaut Courtois but Chelsea soon regained control of the contest.
Eden Hazard calmly finished into the corner after collecting Nemanja Matic's crisp pass while N'Golo Kante scored Chelsea's fourth, and his first for the Blues, when he drifted through the United defence and slotted home with 20 minutes to go.
Courtois ensured his side kept a clean sheet when he produced two good saves late on from Ibrahimovic and substitute Marcos Rojo.

AFC Bournemouth and Tottenham Hotspur battled out a goalless draw in a enthralling encounter at Vitality Stadium.
The home side, who were without the in-form Junior Stanislas with a calf injury, came closest to scoring in the fifth minute when Hugo Lloris deflected with his legs Charlie Daniels’s close-range shot on to the bar.
Spurs hit the woodwork also in the first half when Erik Lamela‘s shot grazed the woodwork after neat play from Dele Alli in the 17th minute.
Artur Boruc was the busier of the two goalkeepers for most of the match, with Harry Arter personifying AFC Bournemouth's endeavour, although late home pressure resulted in Benik Afobe heading narrowly over.
AFC Bournemouth moved up to 10th.
Man of the Match Harry Arter (AFC Bournemouth)

Middlesbrough created the better opportunities with Petr Cech pulling off a series of saves.
Adama Traore went through on goal, only to be denied by Cech, who saved Alvaro Negredo’s shot on the follow-up.
Gaston Ramirez's free-kick hit the crossbar and had a close-range header kept out by Cech, while Alexis Sanchez’s free-kick forced a fine save from Victor Valdes.
Arsenal thought they had won it in stoppage time when Mesut Ozil turned in Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain’s cross-shot, but the German was offside.

Scott Arfield’s 90th-minute strike stunned Everton and sealed a 2-1 victory for Burnley.
The home side were under pressure from the outset, with Kevin Mirallas forcing Tom Heaton into the first of many saves inside 90 seconds.
Yannick Bolasie’s first PL goal for Everton drew them level on 58 minutes, the winger shooting across Heaton.
Having denied both Lukaku and Bolasie as the match opened up, Burnley hit Everton on the counter in the dying moments.
Johann Berg Gudmundsson’s long-range effort rattled the crossbar and Arfield was on hand to drive home.

Two brilliant strikes from Xherdan Shaqiri ensured victory over Hull City, as Stoke City made it two wins in a row in the Premier League.
Marko Arnautovic could have doubled the Potters’ advantage shortly afterwards but was denied by David Marshall in the Hull goal.
Marshall made further saves from Arnautovic and Joe Allen, as Mark Hughes' side built on their Matchweek 8 victory over Sunderland by the same scoreline.

Goals from Ahmed Musa, Shinji Okazaki and Christian Fuchs ensured Leicester City's first Premier League victory since Matchweek 5 at the expense of Crystal Palace.
Jamie Vardy was named on the substitutes' bench for a PL match for the first time since March 2015, but after Christian Benteke struck the crossbar with a header early on the Foxes took control.
Okazaki made it 2-0 after Damien Delaney's excellent diving clearance fell to the striker.
And after Kasper Schmeichel denied both Wilfried Zaha and Yohan Cabaye with point-blank saves, Fuchs extended the lead with a rifled effort from distance.
Cabaye netted a consolation for Palace from Wilfried Zaha’s cross late on but it proved to be a happy afternoon for the PL champions.

Swansea City and Watford played out a goalless draw at the Liberty Stadium in Bob Bradley’s first home match in the Premier League.
Gylfi Sigurdsson had a long-range effort deflected wide in the first half, while Younes Kaboul’s strike from a free-kick deflected off a Swansea defender and looped over the woodwork with Lukasz Fabianski beaten.
In the second period, Swansea's Mike van der Hoorn was denied by Watford goalkeeper Heurelho Gomes from a free-kick, before substitute Fernando Llorente fired narrowly over.
Sigurdsson hit the post in the closing stages but the last chance fell to Nordin Amrabat, who shot over the bar from the edge of the area with both sides settling for a point.

Winston Reid scored a stoppage-time winner for West Ham United at the London Stadium as Sunderland's winless start went on.
West Ham had twice gone close to scoring through Dimitri Payet who, after a superb run, saw a shot saved by Jordan Pickford and hit an upright.
Patrick van Aanholt fired wide for Sunderland after a one-two with Jermain Defoe, whose 20-yard effort was saved by Adrian while Jack Rodwell headed a corner over.
Simone Zaza had an overhead kick narrowly miss, having seen an earlier strike deflect wide.
Sunderland almost made a flying start to the second half when Wahbi Khazri went through, only to shoot straight at Adrian and Reid punished the Tunisian's miss at the death.

First-half goals by Sadio Mane and Philippe Coutinho were enough to earn Liverpool victory over West Bromwich Albion at Anfield.
Liverpool took the lead 20 minutes in with a wonderful sweeping move instigated by a clever dummy from Coutinho and finished by Sadio Mane from Roberto Firmino's whose cross.
Coutinho doubled his side’s lead 10 minutes before the interval when he received Mane’s pass, sold another dummy and beat Foster with a low shot at his near post.
Adam Lallana fired over and Firmino was denied by McAuley before Foster turned a Dejan Lovren header over.
That goal denied Liverpool going above Arsenal and top on goals scored.

Manchester United produced a stubborn display to claim a 0-0 draw at Anfield which ended Liverpool's winning run in the Premier League.
The best chance of the first-half fell to Roberto Firmino, who headed at the goalkeeper from Daniel Sturridge's cross.
United striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic headed back across goal from a Paul Pogba cross at the start of the second half before Liverpool's Emre Can, making his first league start of the season, forced a fine save from David De Gea with a toe-poked shot from eight yards out.
That chance, and the introduction of Adam Lallana soon afterwards, seemed to spark LiverpoolPhilippe Coutinho hit a shot that was curling into the far corner only for a flying De Gea to push wide at full stretch.
With six minutes to go, Coutinho then played in Firmino who was prevented from shooting by a fantastic sliding tackle from Antonio Valencia.

Watford moved into ninth place in the Premier League table after Jose Holebas' superb strike gave them a hard-fought victory at Middlesbrough on Sunday afternoon.
The 32-year-old sealed victory in the 54th minute with a left-foot strike into the top corner from outside the penalty area after Middlesbrough could not clear their lines.
Goalmouth action was at a premium in the first half, Alvaro Negredo heading a Holebas free-kick just wide of his own goal while the Boro striker could not make clean contact when he was found at the back post by a Gaston Ramirez cross.
Nordin Amrabat's tackle denied Negredo at the start of the second half while Adam Forshaw fired wide for Boro from the edge of the area just before Holebas' winner.

Two goals from Charlie Austin helped Southampton up to eighth place in the Premier League with a 3-1 victory over Burnley.
Austin opened the scoring when he prodded the ball past Heaton at the second attempt after Virgil van Dijk’s header across the six-yard box.
Nathan Redmond made it 2-0 with a drilled finish from a corner floated into the box on the hour mark, before Austin slotted in from the penalty spot after Premier League debutant Sam McQueen, on as a substitute for injured Matt Targett, was tripped by Johan Berg Gudmundsson.
Sam Vokes scored with a spot-kick himself to make it 3-1, following Dusan Tadic’s push on Ben Mee, but Saints saw out the match and stretched their unbeaten run to four league matches.

Diego Costa scored his seventh Premier League goal of the season as Chelsea completed a 3-0 victory over Leicester City at Stamford Bridge.
The Chelsea forward struck in the seventh minute to extend his lead as the PL's top scorer, while Eden Hazard and Victor Moses also found the net.
Chelsea doubled their lead when Hazard raced on to a pass from Pedro to round Kasper Schmeichel on 33 minutes.
The Londoners, who also hit a post through David Luiz’s free-kick, made it 3-0 in the 80th minute when Moses received a clever Nathaniel Chalobah backheel and beat Schmeichel.

AFC Bournemouth achieved their biggest victory in the Premier League with a 6-1 win over Hull City.
AFC Bournemouth defender Charlie Daniels opened the scoring before Ryan Mason equalised for Hull with a deflected shot.
Daniels' defensive colleague Steve Cook restored the home side's lead with a towering header before Stanislas extended it with a penalty on the stroke of half-time.
Stanislas appeared unmarked in the area to score on 65 minutes, while Callum Wilson netted with seven minutes remaining.

A first-half double from Theo Walcott helped Arsenal Swansea City 3-2.
Gylfi Sigurdsson gave Swansea hope before half-time with a curling shot after Xhaka had given away the ball.
After the break Mesut Ozil volleyed in Alexis Sanchez's pass to double Arsenal's lead.

Nolito rescued a point for Manchester City after Everton goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg had saved two penalties in the 1-1 draw at the Etihad Stadium.
but Kevin De Bruyne, who was handed spot-kick duties in the absence of the benched Sergio Aguero, saw his 43rd-minute penalty saved. 
Romelu Lukaku's sixth Premier League goal of the season put Everton ahead on 60 minutes with a cool finish after a breakaway.

Joe Allen maintained his scoring streak as Stoke City recorded their first Premier League win of the season, beating Sunderland 2-0.
The Welshman headed home Marko Arnautovic’scross from close range and doubled his tally shortly before the break with a low shot from the edge of the area.
Jermain Defoe's powerful shot over was Sunderland's best opportunity, while Wilfried Bony twice went close to opening his Stoke account.
CharlieAdam nearly added a third in the closing stages when his 20-yard shot hit a post, as Sunderland's winless start was extended to eight matches.

A late goal by Dele Alli salvaged a point for Tottenham Hotspur after Nacer Chadli had scored for West Bromwich Albion against his former club in a captivating 1-1 draw at The Hawthorns.
Spurs enjoyed the lion's share of possession but found Ben Foster in inspired form in the West Brom goal, denying Alli, Ben Davies and Christian Eriksen. 
Further concern for Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino was the loss of defender Toby Alderweireld to injury in the second half.

West Ham United ended a five-match winless streak in the Premier League with a gritty 1-0 win over Crystal Palace at a wet Selhurst Park.
Manuel Lanzini's neat finish from a cross by Aaron Cresswell, making his first appearance of the seasonChristian Benteke had two chances to level in first-half stoppage time but steered a penalty wide before heading against a post.
Indeed West Ham almost got the next goal as Jason Puncheon headed off his own line on 73 minutes.

Joe Allen cancelled out Anthony Martial’s curling strike as Stoke City earned a 1-1 draw at Manchester United.
After Glen Johnson’s strike was saved by David De Gea, Martial, a substitute, had put United ahead with a superb strike, while in the closing stages Paul Pogba rattled the crossbar with a header.
United could have been ahead earlier but were denied by Stoke goalkeeper Lee Grant, who produced wonderful saves to deny Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Jesse Lingard on the way to earning his side a point.

Southampton earned a sixth successive clean sheet in all competitions as they drew 0-0 at Leicester City.
The visiting side started strongly, with Charlie Austin hitting a post with a volley from an acute angle.
Oriol Romeu made three blocks to deny Leicester after Virgil van Dijk's underhit backpass had allowed Jamie Vardy in on goal.

A high-octane performance from Tottenham Hotspur ended Manchester City’s 100% start to the Premier League season with a 2-0 win at White Hart Lane.
An own goal from Aleksandar Kolarov and a second from Dele Alli ensured Spurs drew to within one point of their opponents at the top of the table.
Kolarov turned into his own net from close range in the ninth minute after a teasing cross from Danny Rose, before Alli netted his second of the campaign after a neat through-ball from Son Heung-min eight minutes before half-time.
Erik Lamela missed the chance to make it three from the penalty spot after Alli was fouled by Fernandinho, before Hugo Lloris denied Sergio Aguero with two sharp stops to inflict Pep Guardiola’s first defeat at Man City.

The match against Burnley at Turf Moor was heading towards a stalemate when a corner was knocked down by Theo Walcott and Koscielny bundled the ball home.
Sam Vokes had the best chance of the first half for Burnley but headed wide when unmarked.
Arsenal were brighter in the second half with Alexis Sanchez their main threat.He had a shot saved by Tom Heaton and fired a volley narrowly wide of the post.
Burnley had chances too, with Petr Cech saving a Johann Berg Gudmundsson header and Michael Keane hitting the Arsenal bar.

James Milner scored his fourth penalty of the 2016/17 Premier League season to give Liverpool a come-from-behind victory at Swansea City.
Milner kept his cool from the spot with six minutes to go after Roberto Firmino was fouled in the area by Angel Rangel as Swansea took the lead on eight minutes when Leroy Fer touched home from close range after Borja Baston, making his first Premier League start, headed a corner back across goal which Mike van der Hoorn touched on.
Liverpool responded on 54 minutes, Firmino heading into the bottom corner from a lofted ball into the box from Jordan Henderson.
Philippe Coutinho's curling effort went just wide soon afterwards before Milner's late goal, which could have been cancelled out

Willian and Diego Costa earned them victory over Hull City at the KCOM Stadium.
Robert Snodgrass's set-pieces were a threat but Antonio Conte's side grew into the match after the break and soon after N'Golo Kante shot over the crossbar, Willian's brilliant curling strike into the top corner gave Chelsea the lead on 61 minutes.
Six minutes later, Nemanja Matic's run from midfield ended with a blocked shot, which fell toDiego Costa who sent a shot into the same corner as Willian for 2-0.
Chelsea remained in control and although Hull brought Abel Hernandez, Tom Huddlestone and Shaun Maloney off the bench, Mike Phelan's side could find no way through.

Patrick van Aanholt's late equaliser rescued a valuable point for Sunderland at the Stadium of Light.
Jermain Defoe spurned an early chance for the hosts, pulling a shot wide from close range, while West Bromwich Albion always looked dangerous on the break.
Defoe had a shot blocked late on but Sunderland's persistence was rewarded when Van Aanholt flicked in Duncan Watmore's cross.

Watford twice came from behind to salvage a 2-2 draw at home to AFC Bournemouth.
Callum Wilson broke the deadlock in the 31st minute, directing Junior Stanislas' cross underneath Heurelho Gomes, and after the break a pulsating affair caught alight.
Having fired just over with an acrobatic effort moments earlier, Troy Deeney equalised for the hosts on 50 minutes when he turned in Nordin Amrabat's centre.
AFC Bournemouth re-took the lead on the hour-mark, when Joshua King struck from distance seconds after replacing Jordon Ibe.
But Watford refused to be beaten and levelled for the second time thanks to Isaac Success's maiden Premier League goal - the final decisive act of the day as Jack Wilshere struck the post with a golden opportunity late on.

The heroics of Dimitri Payet helped West Ham United end a run of four successive defeats with a 1-1 draw against Middlesbrough.
Cristhian Stuani opened the scoring in the 51st minute, heading in Viktor Fischer's cross after Jordan Rhodes had been denied one-on-one by Adrian.

Belgium strikers Romelu Lukaku and Christian Bentekescored as Everton drew 1-1 with Crystal Palace at Goodison Park.
Everton

The home side dominated the first half and their first-half pressure paid off when Jeff Hendrick headed in Steven Defour’s corner.
A minute after Tom Heaton had saved Troy Deeney’sshot, at the other end Michael Keane nodded in Defour’s cross.
The closest Watford came to a goal was when Isaac Success ran down the left on 83 minutes and his shot from a narrow angle was tipped just wide.
The result means Burnley rose to 13th while Watford dropped to 11th.

Goals from Charlie Austin, Dusan Tadic and James Ward-Prowse gave Southampton a 3-0 victory at West Ham United.
After a first 40 minutes with few chances, Austin turned in a cutback from Ryan Bertrand for his fifth goal in his last four outings across all competitions.
Steven Davis was denied the visitors' third by Adrian after another swift break, before West Ham's Dimitri Payet fired narrowly wide and Pierre-Emile Hjobjerg was denied by a fingertip stop from the Hammers goalkeeper.

Manchester United completed a resounding victory over Leicester City at Old Trafford.
’s side responded with four first-half goals from Chris Smalling, Juan Mata, Marcus Rashford and Paul Pogba.
Daley Blind’s corner midway through the first half, while Mata produced a sublime finish on 37 minutes after Jesse Lingard had laid off Pogba’s chipped pass.
Demarai Gray reduced the arrears on the hour but there was no coming back for the defending champions.
Man of the Match: Paul Pogba

Junior Stanislas scored a cracking goal to give Bournemouth their second successive home Premier League win and inflict Everton's first league defeat of the season.
Stainslas scored his first goal since December when he powered a shot from 25 yards into the roof of the net after a pass by Harry Arter.
In a whirlwind start, Callum Wilson had almost opened the scoring in the first minute and Jack Wilshere hit the bar with a deflected shot while Romelu Lukaku was superbly denied by Cherries goalkeeper Artur Boruc at the other end.
Ross Barkley and Yannick Bolasie failed to take chances after the break to salvage a point for the visitors.
: Everton report

James Milner scored two penalties and Adam Lallana, Sadio Mane and Philippe Coutinho were all on target as Liverpool thrashed 10-man Hull to earn their third consecutive Premier League victory.
Mane made it 3-0 before half-time with a fierce drive from outside the area after being set up by Lallana.
less than a minute later, Lallana passed to Coutinho, who curled in the fourth from 25 yards.
Milner completed the scoring with his second penalty after Andrew Robertson fouled substitute Daniel Sturridge.

Son Heung-min continued his fine form in front of goal to give Tottenham Hotspur their fourth win of the season and extend their unbeaten Premier League streak to six matches.
After scoring twice in the 4-0 victory over Stoke City in Matchweek 4, Son repeated the feat to put Spurs 2-0 up against Middlesbrough after 23 minutes.
The South Korea winger’s first came from a neat run and finish after good hold-up play from Vincent Janssen, who led the line in the absence of the injured Harry Kane. 
Son then made it double trouble for Boro with an emphatic curled effort from the edge of the box, and, although Ben Gibson headed home Stewart Downing’s cross in the second half, Mauricio Pochettino’s charges held firm for all three points.

Salomon Rondon’s 91st-minute goal denied Stoke City a first Premier League win of the season.
Joe Allen had earlier broken the deadlock in the 73rd minute, when Xherdan Shaqiri’s cross ricocheted into the path of the Welshman, who made no mistake from six yards to fire past Ben Foster.
West Bromwich Albion thought they had an equaliser moments later when James McClean sent a powerful header towards goal, but Lee Grant expertly flew to his left to tip round the post.

Christian Benteke’s stoppage-time header stunned Sunderland as Crystal Palace fought back from two goals down to win at the Stadium of Light.
Jermain Defoe capitalised upon a defensive error to give Sunderland a half-time lead and the home side looked set for a first league win under David MoyesBut within a minute Joe Ledley pulled a goal back for Palace, who were level with quarter of an hour to play through James McArthur's header.

Manchester City maintained their 100% start to the Premier League season beating Swansea City thanks to a brace from Sergio Aguero and Raheem Sterling’s goal.
But Swansea fought back and went in level at the break through Fernando Llorente's half-volley.
Aguero restored Man City's lead on 65 minutes from the spot, after Mike van der Hoorn's foul on Kevin de Bruyne.

Arsenal ended their recent poor run against Chelsea as three first-half goals blew away the Blues.
The home side went ahead with their first league goal against their opponents in six matches when Alexis Sanchez pounced on Gary Cahill’s error and raced through to score on 11 minutes.
Theo Walcott doubled the lead three minutes later, converting Hector Bellerin’s cross.
Chelsea threatened with Willian shooting just wide, but Arsenal added a third as Mesut Ozil broke away to combine with Sanchez and volleyed home.
Michy Batshuayi came closest to getting a goal back for Chelsea but Petr Cech

Late goals by Juan Zuniga and Troy Deeney helped Watford achieve their first victory over Manchester United in 30 years.
The Hornets took the lead on 34 minutes after Daryl Janmaat cut the ball back for Etienne Capoue to score his fourth goal of the season.
United were level on 62 minutes when Valon Behrami could only deflect Zlatan Ibrahimovic's cross into Marcus Rashford’s path and the 18-year-old netted from close range.

James Tomkins marked his Premier League debut for Crystal Palace with a goal as the Eagles earned a 4-1 win over Stoke City.
The defender, who was forced off at half-time through injury, turned in Jason Puncheon’s free kick with a slight touch nine minutes into his first appearance following his summer move from West Ham United.
Scott Dann doubled Palace’s lead three minutes later.Palace resumed control in the second half, thanks to a curling strike from James McArthur and a fine solo effort from Andros Townsend.

Charlie Austin came off the bench and scored the winner as Southampton narrowly beat Swansea City for their first Premier League victory under Claude Puel.
Puel’s side came close to breaking the deadlock in the first half as Virgil van Dijk saw a powerful header saved by Lukasz Fabianski before Nathan Redmond fired over the crossbar.
Saints were denied a goal three minutes after the restart when Shane Long's shot was cleared off the line by Kyle Naughton.

Harry Kane’s second-half strike earned Tottenham Hotspur a 1-0 win over Sunderland.
Kane struck from six yards out from Dele Alli's knockdown before going off injured against a Sunderland side who finished with 10 men, following Adnan Januzaj’s second yellow card.
Moussa Sissoko flashed wide, while Kane and Toby Alderweireld had efforts blocked by goalkeeper Jordan Pickford as the hosts had 19 attempts on goal in the first half.
But Steven Pienaar spurned the best chance of the opening 45 minutes when he had an effort cleared off the line from six yards out.

Arsenal secured their third win in as many matches with a 4-1 victory over 10-man Hull City at the KCOM Stadium.
The Gunners opened the scoring on 17 minutes when Hull failed to clear and Alexis Sanchez got the final touch from Alex Iwobi's shot.
Jake Livermore sent off for a handball as he blocked Francis Coquelin's goalbound strike.Arsenal did add a second 10 minutes after half-time when Theo Walcott finished after a one-two with Iwobi, but Hull were given a way back into the contest when Robert Snodgrass scored a penalty afterArsenal made sure of the three points with seven minutes to go to when Sanchez fired into the roof of the net and, with time running out, Granit Xhaka netted his first goal for the Gunners with a powerful shot from outside the area to complete the scoring.

Islam Slimani had a Premier League debut to remember as his two goals helped Leicester City claim a 3-0 victory over Burnley.
And the summer signing from Sporting Lisbon then made it two on 47 minutes with another header when a Mahrez cross was deflected into the air by Jamie Vardy.
Leicester ensured victory with 12 minutes left to play when Mahrez's centre from the right was diverted into his own net by Burnley defender Ben Mee.

A dominant performance from Manchester City ensured Pep Guardiola's side extended their 100% Premier League record to five matches.
Kevin De Bruyne's cunning free-kick got the hosts off to a flying start before Kelechi Iheanacho turned home Raheem Sterling's square pass to double the lead by the 25-minute mark.
Iheanacho then raced onto De Bruyne's pass to unselfishly set up Sterling and return the earlier favour, while Ilkay Gundogan got in on the act in the second half.
The midfielder netted on his Premier League debut shortly after the hour-mark, and, although Nolito was shown a red card late on for an altercation with Adam Smith, it did little to take the gloss off of Guardiola's fifth PL victory as City head coach.

Nacer Chadli was involved in all his side's goals as West Bromwich Albionran out 4-2 winners over West Ham United at The Hawthorns.
Michail Antonio and Manuel Lanzini briefly gave West Ham hope with quickfire strikes but Tony Pulis' side dug in and held firm for victory.

Gareth Barry scored on his landmark 600th Premier League appearance to help Everton come from behind to beat Middlesbrough at Goodison Park.
The visitors took the lead on 21 minutes when Alvaro Negredo's challenge on Maarten Stekelenburg for George Friend's cross resulted in the Everton goalkeeper conceding an own goal.
The home side responded, when Barry, lurking at the back post from a corner, fired in for his 52nd Premier League goal.
Seamus Coleman made it 2-1 with a driving run and cool finish on 42 minutes from Romelu Lukaku's pass.Lukaku was on the scoresheet when he got a faint touch on Yannick Bolasie's cross to give Everton a two-goal cushion at half-time.

Liverpool held off a spirited Chelsea fightback to earn a 2-1 victory at Stamford Bridge on Friday night.
Antonio Conte’s men had come from behind to claim points in two matches already this season, but Dejan Lovren’s volley and a stunning Jordan Henderson strike meant Diego Costa’s goal was too little, too late for the hosts.
Lovren put Liverpool in front on 17 minutes when he volleyed into the far left corner of Thibaut Courtois’ goal after a deep cross from Philippe Coutinho.
Chelsea, who handed David Luiz a first appearance since returning to the club, pulled one back when Costa struck from close range on 61 minutes.

Romelu Lukaku scored a hat-trick as Everton completed a resounding 3-0 victory over Sunderland at the Stadium of Light.
Sunderland might have gone ahead in the 10th minute when Jermain Defoe reacted first to Adnan Januzaj’s deflected shot, only to fire over the bar as goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg closed in.
Everton had an even better chance to take the lead just three minutes later when Yannick Bolasie, who was a threat all night, picked out Lukaku whose bullet header was tipped over superbly by Jordan Pickford.
Lukaku looked as though a goal drought that dated back to 12 March might continue when he came inches away from turning Seamus Coleman’s angled drive into the netbut he finally capitalised on his excellent service when heading in Idrissa Gueye’s perfectly flighted centre on the hour.
Lukaku thundered a shot on the turn against the crossbar three minutes later but within five he had a second, heading in again after Bolasie provided a pinpoint left-wing centre.
A memorable night for the 23-year-old was complete when he raced on to a wonderful through-ball from Kevin Mirallas and finished with aplomb.

Diego Costa's superb overhead kick with only nine minutes to gorescued a point for Chelsea as they claimed a 2-2 draw against Swansea City in a thrilling match at the Liberty Stadium.
Chelsea dominated the opening period and took the lead on 18 minutes when Costa fired into the bottom corner when Swansea failed to clear their lines.
Gylfi Sigurdsson, who had Swansea's best chance of the first half with a shot that just drifted wide, equalised on 59 minutes from the penalty spot after he was fouled by goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois following a smart Swansea counterattack.
The hosts then took the lead three minutes later when Blues defender Gary Cahill was caught in possession and Leroy Fer's shot just crossed the line off the legs of Courtois.
But it was Chelsea who had the final say and as the ball dropped from the sky after Branislav Ivanovic's shot was blocked, Costa rose to acrobatically score and to maintain his side's unbeaten start to the season.

Kevin De Bruyne and Kelechi Iheanacho were both on target as Manchester City overcame Manchester United 2-1 at Old Trafford.
De Bruyne scored the first on 15 minutes, reacting quickest to Iheanacho’s flick-on from a long punt by Aleksandar Kolarov.
The Belgian was prominent in the second goal, curling a left-foot shot off the far post, the ball bouncing to Iheanacho to finish from close range.
United found a way back into the match when goalkeeper Claudio Bravo dropped Wayne Rooney’s free-kick, and Zlatan Ibrahimovic reacted with a superb half-volley to score his fourth goal in as many league matches.
Substitute Marcus Rashford made a lively contribution for United, but despite chances at both end, the score remained in City's favour by the final whistle.

Callum Wilson’s goal 11 minutes from time earned AFC Bournemouth their first victory of the Premier League season at the expense of West Bromwich Albion.
Ben Foster and his rearguard kept the hosts at bay, while Saido Berahino had a close-range effort kept out at the other end by Artur Boruc.
The striker flicked Adam Smith's cross into the far corner for the winner.

Santi Cazorla’s stoppage-time penalty gave Arsenal a comeback 2-1 victory against Southampton at Emirates Stadium.
Referee Bobby Madley pointed to the spot after Jose Fonte had brought down Olivier Giroud, with Cazorla sending Fraser Forster the wrong way to seal victory in the 95th minute.
Saints took the lead when Dusan Tadic’s free-kick was tipped on to the crossbar by Petr Cech, only for the ball to ricochet off the Arsenal goalkeeper’s back and into the goal.
Arsenal, who handed a debut to Lucas Perez and Skhodran Mustafi, levelled in spectacular fashion, from Laurent Koscielny's bicycle kick after Saints had failed to clear a corner.

A brilliant stoppage-time free-kick by Robert Snodgrass gave Hull City a 1-1 draw at Burnley.
After a closely contested first half with few clear-cut chances, Steven Defour put Burnley on course for back-to-back home wins with a superb strike.
The summer signing scored his first Premier League goal when he ran from his own half and found the bottom corner of Eldin Jakupovic’s goal with a powerful shot.
But, after Hull had penalty claims turned down when Tom Heaton challenged Hull’s club-record signing Ryan Mason, Snodgrass curled a free-kick past the left hand of the Burnley goalkeeper in the 95th minute to earn a point.

Goals from Christian Benteke and Wilfried Zaha sealed Crystal Palace’s first victory of the Premier League season as they won 2-1 at Middlesbrough.
Daniel Ayala put Boro on level terms with another brilliant header, from Stewart Downing’s centre.
But Zaha got the winner in the first minute of the second half, slotting past Victor Valdes after dispossessing George Friend to inflict the hosts’ first defeat since their return to the top flight.

A glut of second-half goals gave Tottenham Hotspur their second successive 4-0 victory over Stoke City at the bet365 Stadium.
Son Heung-min opened the scoring in the 41st minute before doubling the lead 11 minutes after the break, striking superbly from the edge of the area to give Christian Eriksen his second assist of the match.
Dele Alli added a third before the hour, turning in Kyle Walker’s cut-back.

Watford recorded their first win of the season after coming from two goals down to beat West Ham United 4-2 at London Stadium.
Michail Antonio scored twice with first-half headers, the opener from a Dimitri Payet corner before the Frenchman’s rabona cross picked out the West Ham winger at the far post.
The visitors were level by half-time after Odion IghaloRoberto Pereyra teed up Etienne Capoue for his third Premier League goal of 2016/17 before Watford defender Jose Holebas struck from distance to reward the Hornets with three points.

Roberto Firmino scored twice as Liverpool marked their first match at Anfield this season with a 4-1 victory over Leicester City.
Sadio Mane added a second by lifting the ball over Schmeichel from Daniel Sturridge’s clever backheel on 31 minutes.
Jamie Vardy then scored in an open goal after Lucas Leiva’s misplaced pass but Adam Lallana restored the two-goal advantage with a ferocious drive after the break.
Liverpool match coverage

Middlesbrough maintained their unbeaten start to the Premier League season as they held West Bromwich Albion to a goalless draw at The Hawthorns on Sunday afternoon.
James McClean had the first clear-cut chance but Boro goalkeeper Brad Guzan was able to smother after he was played in with a fine ball from Darren Fletcher.
Guzan was also called into action to save from Brendan Galloway before half-time while Cristhian Stuani, who scored twice in last week's victory over Sunderland, had Boro's first shot on target in the 73rd minute buthis shot from an angle was saved by Ben Foster.

Two goals from Raheem Sterling helped Manchester City maintain their 100% start to the Premier League, as they beat West Ham United 3-1 at the Etihad Stadium and went level with Chelsea and Manchester United, whom they visit on 10 September, at the top of the table.
Fernandinho headed in from Kevin De Bruyne’s free-kick to put City 2-0 up, and they could have added to that with some scintillating football in the first half.

Tottenham Hotspur and Liverpool shared the points in an exciting 1-1 draw at White Hart Lane.
After a bright start from the home side Liverpool started to get into the match and their half-time lead, through James Milner’s 43rd-minute penalty after Erik Lamela had clipped Roberto Firmino’s heels, was deserved.
The visiting side almost doubled their lead after half-time when Joel Matip hit the bar from a corner.
Shortly after Spurs had forced Simon Mignolet into two saves in a minute the equaliser came when an advanced Danny Rose fired in at the far post after Lamela had flicked on Eric Dier’s cross from the right.
Georginio Wijnaldum and Adam Lallana had chances for a late Liverpool winner but both were denied by Toby Alderweireld.

Chelsea made it three wins from three with a dominant 3-0 defeat of Burnley at Stamford Bridge, thanks to strikes from Eden Hazard, Willian and Victor Moses.
Hazard broke the deadlock with his second goal of the campaign, receiving a pass from Nemanja Matic then running from his own half before curling beyond Tom Heaton from the edge of the box.
Willian, who was back in the side having recovered from a calf injury, doubled Chelsea's lead just before the break, finding a yard of space in the penalty box before firing across Tom Heaton from an angle.
Burnley's chances were few and the scoring was completed in the 89th minute when second-half substitute Moses met Pedro’s cross to give Antonio ConteChelsea match report

A stoppage-time header from Crystal Palace defender Scott Dann denied AFC Bournemouth their first win of the season in an enthralling encounter at Selhurst Park.
Joshua King’s 11th-minute strike, his first of the Premier League season, put the Cherries ahead, netting from an angle.
Yohan Cabaye had the chance to equalise from the penalty spot when Charlie Daniels fouled Christian Benteke, making his PL debut for Palace, but Artur Boruc flew to his right to save. 
Callum Wilson could have but Steve Mandanda in the Palace goal saved his weak effort.
See: Crystal Palace match report

An own-goal by Stoke City goalkeeperShay Given from a missed penalty by Leighton Baines allowed Everton to edge victory at Goodison Park.
Ronald Koeman’s Everton had plenty of possession in the first half, but laboured to create clear opportunities, with recent signing Yannick Bolasie always a handful and Ross Barkley missing one chance.
Six minutes after the break Everton were awarded a penalty when Ashley Williams was fouled by Phil Bardsley.
Baines’s low shot was pushed on to a post by Given, but the ball richocheted off the goalkeeper's head into the net.
Barkley went close to doubling Everton’s lead towards the end, but Given saved his effort, and the Toffees duly sealed a narrow 1-0 victory.

Premier League champions Leicester City registered their first victory of the season at a rain-drenched King Power Stadium with a 2-1 win against Swansea City.
Jamie Vardy opened his account for the campaign after 32 minutes with a trademark goal, racing on to pass over the top from Danny Drinkwater, taking a touch and smashing his shot in off a post.
Riyad Mahrez could have made it 3-0 but his penalty, awarded for a foul on Shinji Okazaki, was saved by Lukasz Fabianski.
Leroy Fer then halved the deficit with a superb header from Modou Barrow’s cross.

Sunderland secured their first point of the season as they drew 1-1 with Southampton at Saint Mary’s.
The visitors took the lead when Jermain Defoe won and scored a penalty after being brought down by Jose Fonte with 12 minutes remaining. 
The Black Cats' lead didn’t last long though as substitute Jay Rodriguez equalised five minutes later following a mistake by Jordan Pickford in the Southampton goal. 
The Sunderland goalkeeper had made a number of good saves but was left distraught when Rodriguez’s low strike from outside the area squirmed under his body.
Southampton match report

Arsenal secured their first win of the season with a 3-1 victory against Watford at Vicarage Road.
The Gunners took the lead on nine minutes courtesy of Santi Cazorla’s penalty after Nordin Amrabat was adjudged to have fouled Alexis Sanchez.
The visitors doubled their lead when Sanchez dinked over Heurelho Gomez after Theo Walcott’s low cross; the ball adjudged to have crossed the line by the Goal Decision System.
Mesut Ozil gave his side a three goal advantage at half time when he headed home the Chile international’s cross.
Watford debutant Roberto Pereyra, on as a half time substitute, reduced the deficit with his left foot on 57 minutes.
Watford match report

Substitute Marcus Rashford scored a stoppage-time winner to maintain Manchester United's perfect start to the season and to deny Hull City after a superb defensive display had looked to give them a share of the points.
Rashford, introduced with 19 minutes to go, tapped home from close range in the 92nd minute after Wayne Rooney had kept the ball in play on the byline and crossed into the centre.
Visiting striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic headed just over and backheeled into the side netting in the first half while Davies blocked Rooney's goalbound shot on the line.
Paul Pogba, Anthony Martial, Antonio Valencia, Rooney and Rashford all had attempts for United after the break, while Hull's David Meyler shot just over the bar with time running out, before the late dramatic winner.
See: Hull City match report

Middlesbrough earned their first Premier League win since their return after two strikes from Cristhian Stuani sealed a 2-1 victory over Sunderland at the Stadium of Light.
goals both came in the first half before Patrick van Aanholt struck on 71 minutes for Sunderland, leaving David Moyes seeking his first points of the season.
There seemed little danger when, on 13 minutes, Stuani, one of three changes made by Aitor Karanka, picked the ball up from Alvaro Negredo 40 yards away from the Sunderland goal.Sunderland put Boro under pressure but often their final pass was awry, with a cross by Lynden Gooch just eluding Adnan Januzaj and Jermain Defoe failing to find Duncan Watmore on a break.
Moyes’s introduction of Jeremain Lens for Paddy McNair at half-time made a difference for Sunderland.Five minutes later, Defoe looked set to score but his goalbound shot was blocked by Ben Gibson.

Michail Antonio scored the first Premier League goal at the London Stadium as his close-range header gave West Ham United a 1-0 win over AFC Bournemouth.
The winger, deployed at right-back in the opening weekend defeat at Chelsea, capitalised on his advanced position in the absence of injured Dimitri Payet by heading in from a few yards out after Gokhan Tore’s cross over goalkeeper Artur Boruc.
AFC Bournemouth had been on course to hold firm in West Ham’s first home league match since moving to their spectacular new venue from the Boleyn Ground, but Harry Arter was sent off in the 78th minute and West Ham took advantage to claim their first points of the season.
Tore hit the wall with a free-kick just outside the area and Enner Valencia stung the fingertips of Boruc from an acute angle.
AFC Bournemouth started the second half quickly, with Hammers goalkeeper Adrian denying Adam Smith and brilliantly pushing a long-range Josh King strike over the crossbar.
The match opened up, with Tore volleying just wide of Boruc’s near post before Arter’s second yellow card, for hauling down Cheikhou Kouyate, with 12 minutes left.
Substitute Jonathan Calleri fired wide after being put clean through on the counter-attack, with the Cherries piling players forward, but the victory was secured in front of over 57,000 fans at the London Stadium.
Michail Antonio (West Ham)

Pep Guardiola’s perfect start to life at Manchester City continued with a 4-1 win over Stoke City at the bet365 Stadium.
Aguero doubled City’s lead with a well-taken header from Kevin De Bruyne's free-kick nine minutes before half-time.
Raheem Sterling was penalised for holding Shawcross, just as the Stoke captain had been in the first half.
Both managers used players off the bench, with Jonathan Walters coming on for Stoke and Kelechi Iheanacho replacing Aguero with eight minutes left.

Sam Vokes and Andre Gray scored their first Premier League goals as Burnley beat Liverpool for the first time in the history of the competition.
The pair struck in the first half to give the Clarets their first Premier League win over their opponents at the fifth attempt.
Gray created Vokes’ early opener – robbing Nathaniel Clyne and feeding the Wales international, who turned and fired home from the edge of the area.
Gray then found the net himself with a low left-foot shot from the edge of the area, after he had collected a pass from record signing Steven Defour on his debut.
Roberto Firmino came closest early in the second half but Clarets goalkeeper Tom Heaton superbly tipped his goalbound effort past the post.
Clyne and Georginio Wijnaldum had late efforts but Burnley held out to record their first win of the season.
: Burnley report | Liverpool report

Substitute Shaun Maloney scored one goal and had a hand in the other as Hull City maintained their 100% start to the season by inflicting Swansea City's first home defeat since February.
Maloney replaced Adama Diomande in the 73rd minute and had opened the scoring within six minutes – chesting the ball home from close range after Curtis Davies headed on a right-wing corner.
Maloney then turned provider – prodding a Robert Snodgrass pass into the path of Abel Hernandez, who coolly slotted the ball past Lukasz Fabianski, who had denied the striker from another chance moments earlier.
Swansea’sThe victory meant it was the first time Hull had won their first two matches in a Premier League season, following last Saturday’s triumph over champions Leicester City.

Victor Wanyama's maiden goal for Tottenham Hotspur gave them their first victory of the Premier League season at the expense of Crystal Palace at White Hart Lane.
Toby Alderweireld should have done better with a free header from eight yards, nodding straight at the Eagles’No 1, before Christian Eriksen – making his 100th Premier League appearance – wasted a golden opportunity to gift Harry Kane a one-on-one.
Kane was in search of a 50th Premier League goal in his 88th appearance andCrystal Palace report

The midfielder’s left-footed drive 10 minutes into the second half looked like earning the Hornets their first win over Chelsea in all competitions since 1999, butBatshuayi found the back of the net with his first Chelsea goal just seven minutes after replacing Oscar, latching on to Eden Hazard’s effort which Heurelho Gomes could only parry out to the feet of the Belgian striker.
Cesc Fabregas, who came on as a substitute himself in the 78th minute, set Costa free with a glorious lofted ball, with the centre-forward making no mistake from inside the box to earn all three points and net his seventh goal in nine Premier League matches in the month of August.

Everton came from a goal down to beat West Bromwich Albion and secure manager Ronald Koeman’s first victory in charge courtesy of strikes from Kevin Mirallas and Gareth Barry.
’s men were back on level terms at The Hawthorns when winger Mirallas exchanged passes with Ross Barkley and slotted a smart acute finish low into the corner.
It was then Ben Foster’sturn to pull off a last-ditch save, deflecting away Ramiro Funes Mori’s header.From the resulting corner Mason Holgate’s shot into the ground was nodded in by Barry right next to the post to send Koeman’s side into the lead on the hour.
Barkley and Romelu Lukaku spurned late chances to extend Everton's lead but the visitors held out to take all three points back to Goodison Park.
: West Brom report |Everton report

Leicester City and Arsenal are still both looking for their first wins of the season after the two sides shared a goalless draw at the King Power Stadium.
On route to the trophy last season Claudio Ranieri’s side only failed to score in three matches but were held as both defences stood out, with the Arsenal back line strengthened by the return of Laurent Koscielny, while Robert Huth also started for the first time for the defending champions.
Jamie Vardy raced into Arsenal’s penalty box within the first minute and forced a last-ditch clearance from the Arsenal back line.
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain provided Arsenal’s first real opportunity, cutting in from the left and whipping a long range strike narrowly wide of the far post.
Petr Cech raced off his line to block out Riyad Mahrez’s sublime through-ball and Leicester’s claims for a penalty when Danny Drinkwater fell under the challenge of Laurent Koscielny were waved away by referee Mark Clattenburg.
As the game opened up in the second half, Mahrez curled a ferocious free-kick just over the bar before Vardy latched on to Marc Albrighton’s delivery but his shot cannoned well wide.
’s men responded with Theo Walcott firing straight at Kasper Schmeichel.Ahmed Musa collided with Hector Bellerin in the box but his claims for a penalty were turned down.

Zlatan Ibrahimovic scored both goals as Manchester United completed their second successive Premier League win of Jose Mourinho’s tenure with a 2-0 win over Southampton.
Ibrahimovic, on his home debut in the English top flight, struck with a 36th-minute header and a second-half penalty to ensure Mourinho’s first match in charge at Old Trafford resulted in victory.
United, for whom Paul Pogba made his first start since rejoining the club from Juventus, gave a commanding performance with the Frenchman, Ibrahimovic and Wayne Rooney all playing significant roles.
Though the Saints create chances in the first half with Shane Long threatening twice, firstly with a shot on the turn on 26 minutes that rippled the side-netting, and then with a scuffed effort with his left foot which he perhaps took too early after being put through by Dusan Tadic they fell behind when Ibrahimovic met Rooney's deep cross with a thumping header
The travelling supporters thought they were back in it when Tadic scored with a header of his own four minutes after the interval but the attempt was ruled out for offside, and within two minutes the visitors were two down.
Jordi Clasie, on for the injured Romeu, tripped Luke Shaw as the full-back raced into the area, and Ibrahimovic did the rest from the spot.

Diego Costa scored a late winner as Chelsea completed a dramatic 2-1 Premier League home victory over West Ham United to get the Antonio Conte era off to a winning start.
Costa produced a wonderful goal in the 89th minute after it had seemed their night would end in frustration when James Collins cancelled out Eden Hazard’s penalty with a 77th-minute strike.
Hazard accelerated down the left flank and bent a right-footed shot narrowly wide of the far post.
Costa caused problems when he raced though on goal only to have his shot saved by Adrian, but West Ham struggled to clear the danger and Cesar Azpilicueta was brought to ground by Michail Antonio as he burst into the area.The Wales international’s initial header from Dimitri Payet’s corner fell to Enner Valencia, whose effort was blocked, but Collins reacted first to the rebound to fire through a crowded area for his fourth career goal against Chelsea.

Zlatan Ibrahimovic marked his Premier League debut with a spectacular goal as Manchester United started the season with a 3-1 win at AFC Bournemouth.
Wayne Rooney added United’s second when he cleverly headed across Boruc after Anthony Martial’s scuffed volley fell into his path, before Ibrahimovic struck in superb fashion.
Adam Smith scored a brilliant goal of his own to give the hosts hope, turning past his marker and blasting into the top corner from just inside the penalty area after a clever pass from substitute Lewis Grabban.
AFC Bournemouth match report

Despite falling behind to Theo Walcott’s strike, Jurgen Klopp’s side raced into a 4-1 lead thanks to a Philippe Coutinho brace and goals by Adam Lallana and Sadio Mane.On 28 minutes Arsenal were awarded a penalty for a foul by Alberto Moreno on Walcott, whose feet were too quick for the Spaniard’s lunge, but Walcott was denied by Simon Mignolet, who guessed right to parry the ball away.
A minute into stoppage time at the end of the first half Coutinho provided a moment of magic, curling free-kick into the top left-hand corner of Petr Cech’s net from 30 yards out
Lallana gave Liverpool the lead four minutes after the restart by chesting down Georginho Wijnaldum’s cross and slotting past Cech, and six minutes later it was 3-1 to the visitors as a delightful team movefound Nathaniel Clyne haring down the left and picking out Coutinho to score again.
Sadio Mane scored a wonderful individual goal on 63 minutes, powering down the right, cutting inside three players and firing into the top corner.
But Arsenal would not lie down.Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain gave the home fans faint hope with a lovely individual goal which left four opponents in his wake and Mignolet fooled by a low shot on 66 minutes, and 11 minutes later Chambers rose to glance in Santi Cazorla’s free-kick.
Read: Arsenal 3-4 Liverpool match report

Newly-promoted Hull City got their 2016/17 Premier League campaign off to a dream start as they stunned Leicester City, the defending champions, 2-1 at the KCOM Stadium.
An acrobatic bicycle kick by Adama Diomande gave the hosts the lead in added time of the first half and Robert Snodgrass scored their second after Riyad Mahrez had levelled from the penalty spot shortly after break.
Just before Diomande’sgoal Leicester had two good chances to take the lead, with Christian Fuchs denied by Eldin Jakupovic and Jamie Vardy’s follow-up thwarted by a saving block by Jake Livermore.In the Foxes’ next attack Vardy blazed over from close range after being picked out by Ahmed Musa’s centre.
Hull punished the champions with a goal from a corner, Kasper Schmeichel pawing out Curtis Davies’ header, only to be beaten by an overhead kick by Diomande who kicked the ball fractionally after team-mate Abel Hernandez, with a similar acrobatic strike.
Mahrez equalised two minutes into the second period after Demarai Gray had been felled by Tom Huddlestone but Hull restored their advantage on 57 minutes when Snodgrass drilled low into the net after Leicester failed to clear Ahmed Elmohamady’s centre.
Leicester pushed in search of an equaliser but the closest they came was when Danny Drinkwater's shot was easily saved by Jakupovic.

Leroy Fer scored late on as Swansea City earned a narrow victory over Burnley at Turf Moor.
It looked as though it might prove to be a frustrating afternoon for Swansea, who twice came close early on through their summer signing Fernando Llorente, who was denied on both occasions by Tom Heaton.
The visitors also passed up a glorious chance to score through Federico Fernandez, when he blazed over from three yards out early in the second half.
Burnley had their chances when Andre Gray fired over from the right on 32 minutes, and Dean Marney's deflected strike at the death was superbly saved by Fabianski, but by then Fer had struck the decisive blow after Heaton could only parry Llorente's goalbound effort following excellent wing play on the left by Wayne Routledge. 
Read: Burnley match report

Salomon Rondon proved West Bromwich Albion’s match winner as Crystal Palace were beaten in their opening match of the Premier League campaign at Selhurst Park.
The West Brom striker also nodded Craig Gardner’s cross wide five minutes before the interval.
For Palace, Connor Wickham also proved a threat, heading Andros Townsend’s cross wide after 13 minutes and sending a left-foot shot wide midway through the first half.
Crystal Palace match report

Ronald Koeman’s reign at Everton started with a 1-1 draw as heroics from his goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg denied Tottenham Hotspur victory at Goodison Park.
Ross Barkley took only five minutes to give the home side the lead with a free-kick before Erik Lamela levelled for Spurs with a glancing header just before the hour.
After Victor Wanyama – playing against his former manager at Southampton – fouled Kevin Mirallas, Barkley’sEverton looked to double their lead with Gerard Deulofeu and Mirallas causing problems for the visitors, who saw their captain Lloris forced off 10 minutes before the break with a hamstring injury, Michel Vorm his replacement.
Kyle Walker sent in a cross that was met by Lamela, who beat young Mason Holgate to the ball, and his header went into the far corner.
Everton match report

Xherdan Shaqiri’s second-half free-kick denied Middlesbrough a winning start to life back in the Premier League as Stoke City came from behind to draw at the Riverside Stadium.
